text:
But next, it's Leroy.
What is his secret talent?
Well, we are about to find out.

Leroy: All the other
competitors today

are going to try
not to get hurt.
I want it to hurt like hell.
My act starts at injury.

In high school,
I started backyard wrestling.
I threw someone over my head

and I drove off a roof
and the rush, the thrill,
it was so addictive.

I found a wrestling school that
would take me in at 17.
And by 18, I was a pro.

Pain is definitely
a byproduct of the fun.

You know, at first,
everything hurts
and then you get used to it.
I love all the judges,

but one of them has
overlooked me for way too long.

I'm a wrestler, but I have not
had my name in the lights

and I deserve a chance
amongst the legends of the ring.
So get ready America,

because I'm mad, I'm bad,
and I'm hungry for pain.

[ Cheers and applause,
horns honking ]
T-Pain: What the hell?

-Ladies and gentlemen...
-I like this.
Man: Here's Leroy Patterson!
[ Laughs ]
T-Pain: [ Laughs ]

Aah! Whoo! Yeah, whoo!
Yeah!
T-Pain: Get out of it.

Yeah, man.
-Body positivity.

-Yeah!
-Oh!

-Whoo!
-Leroy.
My act, it's for everybody.

But my message is for one person
and one person only.

Mr. Cody Rhodes, much like you,
I am a professional wrestler,

but unlike you, I've never had
my name in the spotlight.
I have been rejected

by nearly every wrestling
federation under the sun.

Every time I get one
of these feels like it
was like stapled to me.

-No.
-Yeah.

This one said
that I didn't fit...

the brand.
-[ Groans ]

This one said that
I wasn't worth the flight.
Oh, man.

This one came from a place
that said I would not
make an impact there.

That's stuck in my mind
for a very long time.

-No.
-Oh.
I shouldn't have eaten first.

-No.
-That was too much.

Speaking of
Legends of the Ring

pro-wrestling manager
extraordinaire,

Howdy Price!
-[ Laughs ]
[ Groans ]

I'm just going to move
right ahead and go on

to the legend of
the brass ring.
No.

It's the belief that if you
work through the pain,
climb the corporate ladder,

there's a brass ring
waiting for you to grab it
and you become legendary.

Tonight, there's no brass ring
waiting for me,

but there are
10,000 brass thumbtacks.

Oh, this is a mess, guys.
This is not pro wrestling.

Howdy:
[ Laughing maniacally ]
Howdy is cracking me up.
Yeah. [ Laughs ]

So Mr. Rhodes, I ask you,
are we legendary enough
to join you in the ring?
Because if you say no,

I'm going to throw myself
into this pit of despair below.
You know what you got to do.
What do you say?

...no.
-[ Gasps ]

Okay, well, thank you
for your time.
That's fair.
Aah!

-I'll see you in the car.
-Oh.

Rosario: Oh, my God.
They're all over him.

-No.
-Oh, my God!
T-Pain: [ Laughing ]
Where has this show gone?

They come in all shapes
and sizes, Jennifer.
Yes, they do.

I did appreciate the parody
and I loved Howdy, too.

I thought there was a fun level
of, like, caricature,
I'm dying to know what Cody thinks.

I'm dying to know
where Cody thinks.

That was the worst ever.
It was.
Audience: [ Groans ]
Please answer honestly.
Yes.

Are you actually
a professional wrestler?

Yes, sir.
-How long have you done it?

20 years.
20 years.

Yeah, I found
Freakshow Wrestling,

which I know
you've been there once.
In Vegas, yeah.
I fell in love again.

It was about
putting on the craziest show
we could for our fans and...

I would love to be able
to do that again.

It's good to know
because you would know this
is not pro wrestling.
No, not at all.

Wrestling is not
about the actual bumps.

I've taken tacks,
broken all kinds of bones,
deformed my face.

The only reason I made
any of those sacrifices

was because the most important
thing in wrestling

is the connection
with the audience.

More than anything,
when they care,

then the bumps matter.
Right?
Yeah, I like that.
